output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of soil mechanics, equipping you with the knowledge to analyze soil behavior and its implications in various engineering applications.
output.introduction: Welcome to Soil Mechanics! This course introduces the fundamental principles governing soil behavior and its application in civil engineering. We'll explore soil composition, properties, and how it responds to stress and strain.

chapters.description: Overview of soil mechanics, its importance in civil engineering, and the types of problems it addresses. Basic definitions of soil and its constituents.
Processes of soil formation (weathering, transportation, deposition). Introduction to different soil types: sand, silt, clay, and organic soils.
Defining key soil properties: particle size distribution, specific gravity, void ratio, porosity, degree of saturation, and water content.

modules.moduleTitle: Introduction to Soil and its Properties

chapters.description: Sieve analysis for coarse-grained soils. Hydrometer analysis for fine-grained soils. Understanding particle size distribution curves.
Liquid limit, plastic limit, and shrinkage limit. Plasticity index and its significance in classifying fine-grained soils.
Introduction to the Unified Soil Classification System (USCS). Classifying soils based on grain size and plasticity characteristics.
Definition of permeability and its importance. Factors affecting permeability (grain size, void ratio, soil structure).
Introduction to Darcy's Law for flow through porous media. Application of Darcy's Law to calculate seepage velocity.
Constant head and falling head permeability tests. Understanding the test procedures and data analysis.
Total stress, pore water pressure, and effective stress. Understanding the concept of effective stress in soil mechanics.
Boussinesq's equation for vertical stress distribution due to a point load. Influence of loading on stress distribution.
Introduction to consolidation. Terzaghi's theory of one-dimensional consolidation (qualitative overview).
Definition of shear strength and its importance. Mohr-Coulomb failure criterion.
Introduction to the direct shear test. Advantages and limitations of the direct shear test.
Introduction to the triaxial test. Different types of triaxial tests (UU, CU, CD).
